text:
Nice presentation!
The point closes to my own interests is working on the edge between order and chaos. In computational science, that's my daily work, and it's a real problem that programming environments force me into one or the other. I have often said that Python's success in scientific computing is to its straightforward interfacing with C, which makes it a kind of bridge between the two worlds, though imperfectly.

I wonder where you would place some more recent arrivals on this scale. Clojure, for example, is a Lisp but with a strong accent on immutability. Unison seems fully on the "order" side in terms of your criteria, but feels much closer to a live programming environment.

Given that you want to concentrate on the "environment" aspect, did you consider working with the Unison team? They are concentrating on the "language" part and their language should be a nice fit for your environment ideas.

Nice presentation!
The point closes to my own interests is working on the edge between order and chaos. text:
<@UJBAJNFLK> Thanks! I am glad that someone sees this Order-Chaos balance thing too.
> Clojure, for example, is a Lisp but with a strong accent on immutability.
To me Clojure is more balanced than say Common Lisp, but still quite shifted towards Chaos because of the macros. Sometimes very hard to understand what is going on. I've thought about ways to make meta-programming possible, yet not putting reader into hell. It seems like it requires to make generated code as easy to view as original. That is easier to do in environment where code is stored in database, not in files.

> Given that you want to concentrate on the "environment" aspect, did you consider working with the Unison team? They are concentrating on the "language" part and their language should be a nice fit for your environment ideas.
I know that I should take closer look at Unison, l am sure that I will learn a lot from it.
I just postponing this work, since it doesn't perfectly fit into my vision.
But I know that it is necessary.

I also have an idea of actor-based programming language that I would like to develop using this generic tree editor. I don't talk about it much yet, since I haven't resolved some major issues in its design.

elements.text: Thanks! I am glad that someone sees this Order-Chaos balance thing too.
Clojure, for example, is a Lisp but with a strong accent on immutability.

To me Clojure is more balanced than say Common Lisp, but still quite shifted towards Chaos because of the macros. Sometimes very hard to understand what is going on. I've thought about ways to make meta-programming possible, yet not putting reader into hell. It seems like it requires to make generated code as easy to view as original. That is easier to do in environment where code is stored in database, not in files.

Given that you want to concentrate on the "environment" aspect, did you consider working with the Unison team? They are concentrating on the "language" part and their language should be a nice fit for your environment ideas.

I know that I should take closer look at Unison, l am sure that I will learn a lot from it.
I just postponing this work, since it doesn't perfectly fit into my vision.
But I know that it is necessary.

I also have an idea of actor-based programming language that I would like to develop using this generic tree editor. I don't talk about it much yet, since I haven't resolved some major issues in its design.

text: Thanks <@UMWF81HTP>! I agree this form was very light on details. I might do a v2 survey where I fill out the details a bit more.

elements.text: ! I agree this form was very light on details. I might do a v2 survey where I fill out the details a bit more.

text: I suggest first checking through "<https://www.startupschool.org/library>" and section "Ideas". In addition, I honestly hope that you won't really start your startup based on this kind of form-survey, which doesn't actually have any details. Please fill the "agile business model canvas" (Google it) for each, and then you will get much better feedback.
